name: 4-acetamidobenzenesulfonyl azide
Reason: 4-acetamidobenzenesulfonyl azide has a melting point that we will compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The sulfonyl group (–SO2–) increases the melting point due to the presence of a polar functional group, which enhances intermolecular interactions and raises the melting point by approximately +20°C. The acetamide group (–NH2C(=O)–) introduces a basic unit with a melting point of approximately +20°C due to the presence of a nitrogen atom and the carbonyl functional group. The azide group (–N=N–) also contributes to the melting point, with a value of approximately +10°C due to the presence of a nitrogen atom and the potential for hydrogen bonding. The sulfonamide group (–SO2NH–) can also participate in hydrogen bonding, which may further lower the melting point by approximately +10°C.
